SCHOLARNOTE.P: As a girl MG was called not by her first name but by a diminutive of her second.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG was born in Leeds, probably at 5 Melville Street in the district of Woodhouse. Mother's home 17 was the way she remembered this house.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She was third in a family of five children, four girls (of whom, besides herself, only the eldest survived to adulthood) and one boy. 1: 86
7 She was born late in the day in blizzardy weather, 9 and though her father recorded the precise time in the family Bible, he was not there to run for the doctor, so the baby was delivered by her maternal grandmother. 7, 9

MG begins her autobiography with her local identity: I was Yorkshire born. My forebears, grandparents maternal and paternal, were all born in Yorkshire, in Leeds so far as I know. 7 Born English therefore, she was baptised in the Church of England, when her godmother and godfather had promised quite a lot of things for me of which I knew nothing until later years. 13 As a child she fully accepted this faith, though while she was at school it suddenly came to her that she was not sure that Jesus was God's son, and she also, thinking of her mother, mentally rejected the Catechism's assertion that she was born in sin. She signed the pledge of the Band of Hope, the Anglican children's temperance society (or teetotal society, as they called it), and was moved by Sunday School and even by a Mission at about the same period—yet from another Mission a few years later she precipitately fled. 49, 70-4, 78, 81, 86 She suggests implicitly in her memoirs that her Christian faith was shaken when she discovered in the course of local political work that pious people cared more about the forms of religion than whether poor children got enough to eat. 184-5 For a while she belonged to the Labour Church. She later took up more experimental belief-systems. Though she was never a formal member of the Theosophical Society, 193 she was hugely impressed, and propelled into self-questioning that was new to her, by Annie Besant's Karma (1895), which she felt to be reading her rather than letting her read it. She liked particularly the declaration inside the cover: There is no religion higher than truth. 192 She also took an interest in Christian Science. 184-5 247

Her poor, working-class family enjoyed a certain standing in the local community because of her parents' energetic participation in various social groups, but it remained vulnerable to the many hazards of working-class life.115

By the end of her life MG had lived longer in the USA than in Britain. In the context of her American incarnation, she writes of the capacity to shift from one national viewpoint to another, to accept the existence of more than one patriotism, as not known in the England or the Yorkshire of her growing up, and as dating from the period following the Great War.132 As a girl she left unread a school prize which might have prepared her for these ideas, From the Tan Yard to the White House by Samuel Smiles, in which two boys come to blows over whether George Washington was a patriot or a traitor.131-2

At ten months Mary Eleanor nearly died of measles, and was thought to have been saved by having brandy poured down her throat. She had scarlet fever at about eight and was sent to hospital with the dreaded typhoid fever not long afterwards.18, 24-6

She grew up at 5 Melville Street among industrial working-class housing which was typical of the time but in later parlance a slum. Going to the toilet (except at night, for which a pot was kept under the bed) meant walking up the street to those frightful closets emptied by the nightsoil men in the hours between midnight and dawn. These were later replaced by trough water-closets . . . two families to a closet, where centrally-propelled water would surge randomly and messily through the troughs.17

On bank holidays (poor people seldom had more than one day's holiday at a time) the family would often go by train to some nearby village to walk in the country, and hope that a farmhouse would provide tea.57
They moved during Mary Eleanor's childhood (soon after she was ill with typhoid) from Melville Street to Jubilee Street, but without leaving the district of Woodhouse, let alone Leeds.61

MG's mother, Annie Eliza (Mountain) Gawthorpe, had a little schooling before hard times came and children were forced to take jobs because fathers had lost theirs.8 She became a mill-worker, then escaped the abominated mill to work as a dressmaker for her eldest sister, Emma, who had set up her own business.8 Her work on the family's clothes was important to the family budget.

After the deaths of two of her children, when Nellie (the later Mary) was about ten, Annie Eliza fell seriously ill with rheumatic fever which permanently weakened her, and she was a semi-invalid during her menopause. She did not approve when her husband became a Conservative political agent, both because payment depended on results and because of the high living and drinking which the work involved.115, 11624, 62

MG's father, John Gawthorpe, was a leather currier, who worked at a tannery or leather factory. He was also a church choirmaster, Sunday-school superintendent, cricket-team captain and later an agent for the Conservative Party, as well as a peripatetic newsagent, second-hand book dealer, and sports journalist.28-38115-16 He was intolerant of anybody in authority, and Mary later wrote of him: Enmeshed in the caste system of the England of the day, he was an intellectual soul who would have done brilliantly in an intellectual profession.35 As it was, before the youngest child was born his glaring indiscretion brought a dark cloud upon his family, making his wife unhappy and therefore his children too.21 Some years later Mary realised both that he had debts and that he was not teetotal; she became conscious for the first time of taking her mother's side.26 Her father was not, she realised when she saw more of the world, a very heavy drinker. He got drunk only occasionally, but his spasmodic efforts to give it up never lasted for long, and the money he drank was sorely needed by his family.120-1

MG at nineteen knew nothing about sex, though she knew that when her father came in late that meant no sleep for her mother. When her remaining sister married, she invited her mother to move out of the marital bed into hers. Even when her father came one night to reclaim his wife, Mary did not understand.64-5 Once she was a self-supporting adult, she persuaded the rest of the family to move house without him and her parents unofficially separated.1: 86450118

MG had apparently her last sight of her father when she was marching in a parade in Huddersfield to celebrate the release of herself and other Yorkshire suffragists from jail. He tipped his hat to her and bowed low, eyes gleaming a trifle sardonically for all the respect in the gesture. She ignored him completely. But [she] knew he was proud of his belligerent offspring.128

MG's maternal grandmother, Elizabeth Raney Mountain, was believed to be of French descent. She and her husband were a devoted, long-married pair. Both began as cloth-dressers, though they worked at anything going, as their children had to in their turn from their youth up. In old age this grandmother was almost blind, and she outlived her husband by only a month.7, 9

Mary's other grandmother spoke Yorkshire dialect like her husband, and was conservative in dress (wearing a lace net on her hair), but eclectic in religion, attending church and chapel alternately.11-12 It was from this side that MG thought the family got its ginger and ferment.11
When Mary was seven her baby sister, aged ten months, died of convulsions, and two and a half years later her next-elder sister died of inflammation of the bowels at not quite eleven.22-3

Her surviving and eldest sister, Annie, was optimistic and energetic: when she married, in September 1900, it was into an institution in countless small ways reformed and modernised. She and her husband were the first in the family to emigrate to America, as MG, her mother, and her brother all did later.108-15

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG's sister Annie emigrated to the USA, setting sail with her three-year-old son to join her carpenter husband, who had gone on ahead.

SHORTPROSE.P: MG's brother and youngest surviving sibling, Jim, like her emigrated to the United States. He died there just before she published her memoirs.122

Like all her siblings but one, MG had been taught to read before she went to the local Church of England infants' school, St Michael's, at the age of five. 19 The whole family had the reading habit. 129 Apart from the popular press (including society papers and funny papers), the key was always in the lock of the glass-fronted, well filled bookcase, 129 looking like an invitation. Their collection contained books awarded as prizes to each of their parents, plentiful religious books, the poetry of Christina Rossetti, and George Eliot's Romola (a gift to the mother from the father, who made baffling reference to the author's irregular behaviour). 129 Among Mary's own favourites were Self and Self-Sacrifice; or, Nelly's Story by Anna Lisle and The First Violin by Jessie Fothergill. 130 When her father became a dealer in books their sources of supply increased. 123-43

At the school Mary Eleanor attended the sexes were separated at the age of seven, and she went up into the Girls' department of St Michael's National School. This school prided itself on the fact that National Schools (including church schools) belonged to a system dating back to the parliamentary grant made by the Education Act of 1833, while Board Schools dated from the much later though better-known Education Act of 1870.20, 41

MG later remembered several of her teachers: Miss Gargrave the headmistress, Miss Clara Locke, and Miss Florence Wood. She remembered the last-named for punishing her for talking, with a stroke on the hand. She was guiltless of this offence, and caused a furore by steadily refusing to hold out her hand. She gave in at last rather than be late for her newspaper round with her father, but she later remembered this as her lesson that injustice is possible in the world. She learned less problematic lessons too: reading, spelling (which all her family were good at), dictation, writing, arithmetic, sewing, knitting (which she preferred to sewing), singing, history, geography, and scripture. When Mary Eleanor was in the third standard Miss Gargrave was displaced by a male head and the boys' and girls' departments were amalgamated to the extent of sitting each on a different side of the same classroom. Male teachers were a novelty, but Mary's father supported the ousted headmistress. In standard six she was for the first time asked to write in her own words. Her learning was not entirely confined to school: she once attended a temperance class taught by Frances Willard, who was visiting from the USA.41-3, 45-6, 49, 78 Her closest school friend, Elsie, later married a cousin of her own fiancé.158

One of the poems MG had to learn for recitation was Meddlesome Matty by Ann Taylor (later Gilbert).47 (MG thought it was by the other sister, and later regretted that she never did have it out with Jane Taylor, drat the woman for this, The Violet, and that egregiously silly Little Fish, all of them inculcating modesty and obedience.)68 She loved, however, most of the hymns which she regularly sang, as well as, when she met them through Miss Lees (the most learned of her Sunday-school teachers), Victor Hugo and Walter Scott.71, 82

From St Michael's MG, aged thirteen, won a scholarship to a local high school, but it was awarded without maintenance. (The dictation in the scholarship exam had been about the migration of terns, a seabird unknown to a city child. She felt sure the word turn must be wrong, and in fact in spelling the word phonetically spelled it correctly, but at the cost of near-terror.) Her family could not afford her being taught without maintenance, so she became a pupil-teacher at St Michael's instead. She continued to study in the evenings and on Sundays, and made the vicar gasp when she told him she wanted one day to take a degree.49-50, 80, 86 Only her maternal grandfather applied to her studies an antifeminist proverb: A whistling woman and a crowing hen86 (used by another Yorkshirewoman, A. S. Byatt, in 2002 to title a novel).

Apprenticeship included some part-time attendance at the Pupil-Teacher Centre in the Leeds School Board offices. There MG continued with largely the same subjects as at school, with the addition of French, educational theory, psychology, and at the last moment, with college entrance in mind, Latin as well. The various books which came to her as prizes included a volume of Sir Walter Scott's poems, three volumes of works by the Brontë sisters, Aylwin by Theodore Watts-Dunton, and, later, a biography of Milton and Our Hundred Days in Europe by Oliver Wendell Holmes. Exams were held each year and after passing with a second class for two years MG reached first-class level in her third and fourth years. One of her pupil-teacher friends was Ethel Annakin, who later as Ethel Snowden became a fellow suffragist and feminist, a viscountess (when her husband's political services were honoured), and the first woman governor of the BBC.96-101, 102-3, 140

Going to college would have been the natural sequel to doing well as a pupil-teacher. Several people tried to make it possible for MG to follow this route, and when she wrote her memoirs sixty years later she still felt defensive about turning them down. Both her current principal and her Aunt Eliza offered to finance her further study, and she herself sat the entrance exam for Victoria University (now the University of Manchester) and was awarded a Queen's Scholarship, First Class. (She felt she ought to have come higher up the graded list of results.) When her beautifully-written letter of application to enter in 1900 was returned with a request for one in her own handwriting, she wrote to assure the authorities, with another sample, that the writing was really and truly her own. 102 Yet she still felt that her mother needed her to be earning, which she could do if she continued to study part-time only, but not if she went to college. She felt that this was her immediate duty. 101-5 Continuing her studies in her next job, as an Assistant Teacher, she passed her first and second-year Certificate exams with first-class results in each part: what was called a double-first. The actual certificate, the government parchment, would not be issued till after another eighteen months' probationary teaching, when she was nearly twenty-one. 148

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG received her government parchment marking her Teaching Certificate.

SHORTPROSE.P: She had recently been taking classes in singing at Leeds College of Music (another subject in which she was awarded a scholarship). A course in elocution at the same institution proved useful later on, in the suffrage campaign. The summer after receiving her Certificate she began studying by distance learning towards an L. L. A in Moral Philosophy and Physiology. She sat by post the examination for her L. L. A. (Lady Literate in the Arts) degree from St Andrews University, which had instituted this qualification for women before they were allowed to be regular members of any Scottish university.163-5, 170-1

MG's later educational endeavours continued through 1904-5, running concurrently with teaching (as the family breadwinner) and increasing political activity. She felt as if this was a private obsession, which would be incomprehensible to anyone in the world except perhaps another autodidact, H. G. Wells, whose Experiment in Autobiography had a profound influence on her. For various courses she was awarded a first in hygiene and a second in education. 141, 186-7
All this work undertaken very much on the run was not compulsory. There were no personal gains . . . . No one, literally, cared whether I or anyone else continued A.C.P. into L.C.P. into F.C.P.,img: not tagging these degrees since dont know either what they are or whether she got them. as did Wells, or battled L. L. A. to its ultimate certificate. The mad, sad fact was that I liked studying for its own sake and examinations were the approved mode of testing what had been learned. 187 In 1915 she took a secretarial course at Kensington College.

MG's first work experience was helping her father deliver newspapers and magazines, then running his journalistic copy from sports fields to the newspaper office: both jobs requiring self-reliance. Then, from the age of thirteen, she spent four years as pupil-teacher of primary-age children at St Michael's National School. She learned there that she liked teaching and was good at it (she soon gave up using the cane).28-9, 38, 88, 93 Her testimonial from the headmaster when she completed her apprenticeship seemed to me an almost unbelievable instrument of praise.88

After her momentous decision, at the age of nineteen, that she must support her mother instead of going on to university, MG decided to leave St Michael's (though they offered to raise her salary to £45 a year). She became an assistant teacher at St Luke's Boys School (much further from home and entailing long street-car rides), at £50 a year. She taught there for five years, taking classes at every level. She was ready to try anything, and even taught a class of boys to knit.105-6, 145, 148 She remained a teacher in and around Leeds until spring or early summer 1905, though a year before this she moved to the then countrified Bramley school (where she observed when her class was entered for a singing contest, that she was supposed to remain impassive whether they won or lost). From this post she resigned after a year, with no prospects in sight but with her career as a political activist, writer, and journalist barely visible on the horizon. She was soon receiving some remuneration as secretary of the local Women's Labour League. While working for them she resisted persuasion to join the WSPU.187-90, 218, 225118, 122-3
As a pupil-teacher MG developed a crush (a word then unknown to her) on a girl named Margaret. She purloined a book as a gift for her, first copying on the flyleaf a poem on the name Margaret.94

MG's health was still not good. As a pupil-teacher, although she would make light of ailments (she told nobody when she fell and, as it turned out, broke her finger), she went down with pneumonia after she was confined to working in the cold cloakroom during a school bazaar because her home-made voile dress was disapproved of. Her eldest sister contrasted with her in physical strength and energy; the eldest, she wrote, is often far the healthiest in families pinched by want.90-3, 108-9

In late summer 1902 a summer cold developed into something serious, and she was persuaded to undergo general anaesthesia in order to have a nasal block removed. Her response to the operation drew the comment neurotic,171 but recovery, first at Scarborough and then in a convalescent home at Ilkley, took weeks.171-2

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A few months after turning twenty-one, MG took the initiative and moved her family (parents and brother) from Jubilee Street in Woodhouse to Southmount Terrace, Beeston Hill, another district of Leeds.

SHORTPROSE.P: The move cut down her travelling time to work. The house was not large, but it was not a back-to-back. It had its own facilities, a little backyard and the tiniest suggestion of a [front] garden.151 Her father, however, was unhappy about this move, which symbolised his loss of power in the family. Very soon he announced . . . that as for him he was going back to Woodhouse. . . . With unbelievable speed the rest of Father's family acted.152 Mary got part of her salary advanced: she and her mother and brother house-hunted in their new area, found something smaller and cheaper at the junction of Fulham and Greenmount,153 and moved there with their personal belongings, leaving the furniture (except the piano, for which they took over paying the instalments). This was for Mary a major step into maturity and freedom.152-5
Money was easier without her father as part of the family; they had the salaries of both Mary and her brother. Their mother seemed healthier, and rejuvenated.157

MG, as a householder, found herself in possession of a municipal vote, a property vote157 in local elections. The fact that this came without the right to a vote in parliamentary elections was a small push towards her later suffragist politics. Soon after this came her discovery, through her fiancé, of socialism and the Labour movement.157, 173

Just before this family drama MG had acquired a boyfriend. He has been identified as T. B. (Tom) Garrs, a compositor on the Yorkshire Post and an enthusiast about music, whom she had met once years before. In her memoirs she calls him by the initials F. L., apparently for First Love. Her mother liked him at once. Though Mary's home life had set her against marriage (she asked F. L. to stay away while she and her family made the break with her father), the pair soon formed the intention of marrying one day, after a long engagement. Garrs was already an active socialist, and with him Gawthorpe explored the worlds of politics and of the arts.155-62118-19under Mary Gawthorpe But this relationship had not matured to the point of marriage when MG began constantly travelling for the political work which absorbed her. Her fiancé was simultaneously uneasy and approving228-9 about this work, while Gawthorpe herself and her mother felt uneasy about the possibility of combining it with marriage and children, despite the shining and unrepentant example of Emmeline Pankhurst.228-9 Garrs helped out when Gawthorpe was suffering the attentions of a fellow-activist and visited her when she was in prison for suffrage activities,231128 but the relationship eventually petered out.

Tom Garrs introduced MG to Socialist politics. This was a time, she wrote later, when in a place the size of Leeds the labour movement was deeply aware but not yet moving, much less on the march.181 She joined the Independent Labour Party (ILP), the Women's Labour League, and the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (of which she helped to found the Leeds branch), and became active in a range of organizations at a local level: the National Union of Teachers (NUT), the Committee for the Feeding of School Children or Children's Relief Committee set up by the Lord Mayor of Leeds, and the Leeds Arts Club, which was run by the Fabian A. R. Orage. She was quickly invited onto the executive bodies of most of the institutions she joined.1: 86119, 122under Mary Gawthorpe

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG attended the meeting which set up the Lord Mayor's Children's Relief Committee in Leeds, providing help for families which had difficulty feeding their children.

SHORTPROSE.P: The meeting was called in view of the temporary distress consequent upon depression in trade.181 Gawthorpe and her associates thought this distress went beyond the temporary into deep-seated causes, as had been revealed by the physique of army recruits for the Boer War. The meeting, however, explicitly confined itself to the temporary. When discussion moved to the thriftlessness and intemperance of the poor, MG got to her feet with an impassioned speech based on her own experience. Nevertheless, when the committee was struck, she was at first the only labourite on it, the only person not a well-known, leading citizen. In five months 323,414 dinners were provided (only at recognised centres, so children who could not go to school because they had no boots got no dinner). The food was often a lentil roast, guaranteed not to cost more than about a halfpenny a meal,181-3 and the recipe advised can be fried in slices on the second day.183

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Lord Mayor's Children's Relief Committee in Leeds stopped providing free food because they could not cover costs for the next week, although, as MG wrote, there were still hungry and underfed children.

SHORTPROSE.P: The committee was disbanded in October, handing the balance of their funds to some voluntary body yet to be formed, and leaving Gawthorpe feeling the gulf between middle-class do-gooders and the Labour movement, and the impossibility of changing social conditions without having the vote.186119

MG's great ally on the Lord Mayor's Children's Relief Committee was Dr William Hall. He too wanted continuing action against hunger, and he observed that Jewish children were better fed than Gentile children from the same slum areas, apparently because Jewish charities were readier to minister to the body instead of predominantly to the soul. He hinted to MG his impatience with the pious tone of the Lord Mayor and others on the committee.184-5

MG equally admired A. R. Orage and Holbrook Jackson, founders of the Leeds Arts Club. At the Club she also met Edward Carpenter, W. B. Yeats, G. K. Chesterton, George Bernard Shaw, and Florence Farr (whom she calls Beatrice).191-2, 196-7 Activists in the Labour movement and the suffrage movement constituted an adult family grouping.203

MG records in detail a drama in miniature198 when she was visiting Orage at his home, and he suddenly, without warning, pulled her close and said Kiss me. She did so (responding instinctively), and found that his response was a little laugh, an elated, triumphant laugh. She told F. L. about this at once, and did not again step upstairs when visiting Orage.199img: dont think violence wd be right for this. Later F. L. repelled by his mere presence the unwanted attentions of an eccentric socialist who seemed elderly to the young MG.231

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: For reasons undefined except a vague need for change, MG formed the desire to live in the country, and moved with her family from Beeston Hill to Bramley, then an oasis of peace where their kitchen looked out on fields.

SHORTPROSE.P: This was just before her sister emigrated to America.

During this period, she wrote later from the USA, she was blown by two powerful and regular winds which seemed to keep changing direction, those of the Labour movement and the Woman Suffrage movement.203 The differences were just beginning to emerge between the Pankhurst wing of the suffrage movement, which advocated escalating violence, and the more moderate wing. The split did not become official until October-November 1907. MG wrote: I was virgin soil in the weighty matters of cliques and struggles for leadership.215 Difficulties between the suffrage movement as a whole and the labour movement were also in the air.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG (inspired by the notorious arrest of Annie Kenney and Christabel Pankhurst in Manchester on 13 October 1905) worked with Isabella Ford to launch and run the Leeds Women's Suffrage Society.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Women's Social and Political Union was only just spreading from Manchester, its birthplace in Lancashire, across the Pennines into Yorkshire. MG worked with Christabel Pankhurst in Glamorgan, Wales, to mobilize mining communities for Labour and against the local Liberal candidate, and by 1909 she was chief organizer for the original Lancashire branch.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG became a paid organizer for the national Women's Social and Political Union. She worked for the WSPU until autumn 1911 and became one of its leading organizers and speakers.

SHORTPROSE.P: The WSPU had been founded on 10 March 1903. MG always felt herself something of a late-comer. In this job she was paid two pounds a week, distinctly more than she would have expected at this age as a school-teacher.457125
She could not have afforded to work full-time for the WSPU without being paid. She supported her mother (who received half her wages every week) as well as herself.450123, 125

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG left her teacher's pay-packet, a little envelope containing her entire month's salary, in the pocket of her coat in Bramley school cloakroom, and it was stolen.

SHORTPROSE.P: Up to then, she said, perfect trust and safety in the school surroundings was normal. She was badly shaken by this loss, which forced her to borrow from her boyfriend F. L. Much later she concluded that the thief might have been a political enemy.210

Before she became a paid employee of the WSPU, MG's furthest foray away from home was to Edinburgh in August 1905. She followed this by travelling to the Lake District soon afterwards and Oxford (her first introduction to the Midlands) the next Whitsun. The first and last of these trips were made in connection with Labour activism. In the ancient seat of learning she spoke eloquently in favour of extending its privileges more widely.203-5, 211, 212

For these four years she lived a semi-itinerant life.458 Besides Leeds and London, she campaigned for labour or suffrage or both in Cockermouth (where an election in 1906 was crucial), Teignmouth, Oldham (where she and Jennie Baines hid in the flies at the theatre to heckle a Liberal speaker on stage), Jarrow, Manchester, Liverpool (where she met with girls from one factory after another), Huddersfield (where the strong socialist women delighted her), Birmingham (a hard nut to crack because of its size), Rochdale, Stockport, Preston, Morecambe, Harrogate, Belfast, and the scarred and ravaged Welsh mining villages whose names (from Maesteg to Pontycymer) she found exotic. Manchester became her base from the end of August 1908.458123, 129, 132, 133, 134-5, 150225-7, 229, 232, 235

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG arrived in London representing the Leeds Women's Labour League.

SHORTPROSE.P: On this occasion she returned to Leeds and resumed travelling and working for the cause, but it was not long before she moved to London.219

Her immediate task was to attend a meeting about providing food for destitute schoolchildren. She then made part of a parliamentary delegation on this topic, attended a meeting about the Sweated Industries Exhibition, and chaired a meeting about conditions for women working as assistants in the printing trade219-22

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG was arrested for the first time, for suffrage action in disrupting the opening of Parliament in London; together with many suffrage leaders, she was sentenced to two months in Holloway Prison.

SHORTPROSE.P: It was apparently MG who began the action, when Prime Minister Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman refused to meet the suffrage deputation and she sprang on one of the sacred velvet chairs, and began to speak.127 She found it, however, no easy matter to be arrested: she was not well enough known to be a prison target. Two huge policemen pulled her from the chair and ejected her despite the combined physical efforts of Emmeline Pankhurst and Emmeline Pethick-Lawrence, and she had thrice to climb the railings outside, beginning a speech three times over in three different places, to secure her arrest.239-40 This was her baptism of fire.127 The horrors of prison were only slightly mitigated by kind gifts of books from the outside. MG first read Charlotte Perkins Gilman's Women and Economics and Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Woman (as well as Plato's Republic) in Holloway.247 This was the first of several imprisonments for her; it ended when quite without warning she and her companions were released half-way through their sentence. Even when taken ill, in 1910, she continued to campaign from her bedside.1: 86-7128
She and Annie Kenney left prison with about thirteen shillings each as payment for their compulsory knitting of prison stockings.247-8
She went on hunger strike in prison and suffered force feeding on several occasions, which was hard on her somewhat fragile health.

In a passage on prison conditions which she did not include in her published memoir, MG recalled her distaste for prison garb, especially the nauseating undergarment . . . stained as it was in a revolting and suggestive manner in spite of whatever sanitary precautions may or may not have been taken in those days. (Constance Lytton had not yet undertaken her campaign for women prisoners to be issued with sanitary towels.)128

During her time with the WSPU, MG worked with Christabel Pankhurst (who was twenty-four when Gawthorpe first met her, before she had yet met Isabella Ford), whom, like Ethel Snowden, she knew from her time in Leeds.180-1 She recorded her first meeting with Ford (a somewhat fraught occasion when Ford and the future Snowden apparently tried to discipline Gawthorpe for speaking on behalf of the movement without specific authorization) and her first sight of Emmeline Pankhurst.214-16 Ford later became a close associate. Gawthorpe also worked to a lesser degree with Sylvia Pankhurst, and many others. Emmeline Pethick-Lawrence became a particularly warm friend because of a shared enthusiasm for Cecil Sharp folksongs.217 At meetings organised by the Leeds ILP, MG met Teresa Billington and Frederick Pethick-Lawrence. In London she met Socialist and feminist women like Margaret MacDonald (wife of the future Prime Minister, who died tragically young in 1911), Mary MacArthur, Gertrude Tuckwell, Annie Kenney, and Charlotte Despard. She had warm relations also with Rose Lamartine Yates, Henrietta Lowy, and Jennie Baines.180-11: 86452122, 125, 130 She held in affection and admiration such Labour stalwarts as Keir Hardie (who was one of the first to visit the suffragist prisoners in Holloway) and Robert Smillie.225, 245

MG's rate of work was extraordinary. During the first six months of 1907 she took part in seven election campaigns. It appears that her loyalty to the WSPU was unaffected by the shifts and splits within the suffrage movement towards the end of this year.130, 131-2

One of her many arrests (this one together with Dora Marsden and Rona Robinson) came at Victoria University, Manchester, on 4 October 1909, when they faced the prospect of prison and force-feeding, though in the event this did not happen.146-7
In 1907 MG was ill with appendicitis and recuperated slowly; she herself felt that her health was permanently affected at this time.131

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG, who was involved with Dora Marsden in impeding Winston Churchill's election rallies in Southport, received grave internal injuries when she was struck by one of the stewards.

SHORTPROSE.P: This description comes from Cicily Fairfield (the future Rebecca West), who was observing the election campaign. West also said that stewards commonly used great physical violence, and she attributed Gawthorpe's health breakdown directly to this blow. Gawthorpe and another woman who had also been injured brought a charge of assault, but their case was dismissed by a court.149

Sylvia Pankhurst later wrote that MG was totally incapacitated for several months and an invalid for several years.450 It is remarkable how many reference reports of her illness fail to mention its source in injury.1: 87 She went on driving herself hard even when she was ill, so it is difficult to tell just how much she was slowed down. She continued to feel guilty about not finishing the work she had undertaken.458
During her illness, and as long as she remained in England, MG received financial help from suffragists who were more materially comfortable than she was.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG resigned her position with the Women's Social and Political Union (she had been trying to continue working while bedridden).

SHORTPROSE.P: She then accepted Dora Marsden's offer of a position as co-editor on The Freewoman, although she had turned down Marsden's first suggestion on the grounds that she wanted to finish [her] work in the WSPU properly.451 Marsden was pressing: she badly wanted Gawthorpe's established name to give her periodical a kick-off.455 The first number of The Freewoman appeared on 23 November. Gawthorpe later wrote: had I had the least inkling that Dora's first number was to be launched with an attack on the Women's Social and Political Union I should never have allowed myself to be named as joint editor.456 She resigned in March 1912 because Marsden's anti-WSPU line did not reflect her views, and was bringing a flood of complaints from her WSPU friends and contacts (to many of whom she had innocently recommended The Freewoman).451

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: While still employed on The Freewoman though not by the increasingly militant WSPU, MG engaged in smashing windows of government buildings in support of a (male) hunger striker.

SHORTPROSE.P: Imprisoned on this account, she mounted both a hunger and a thirst strike before being released on account of her frail health.178

She had no objection to this kind of violence against official property, though she felt that increasing WSPU militancy was likely to result in escalation of violence against people on both sides. She gave a lot of time this year to the forced-feeding scandal and campaigning for signatures to a petition against it. She attempted to organize a national women's hunger strike for October 1912, but did not succeed: this was the end of her suffrage work.451-2

MG tried living in various different places in an attempt to benefit her health, as was common for invalids at that date. She spent the winter of 1914-15 visiting Italy (which entered the First World War as an ally of Britain in spring 1915).

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG sailed from England for the United States with her mother, and settled with her married sister, Annie, in Monroe, New York; at her departure she entrusted her suffrage archive to Rose Lamartine Yates.

SHORTPROSE.P: The legal status of this move was important. MG and her mother did not enter the USA as immigrants (Mary as a known radical activist would not have been welcome there), but for a family visit. She subsequently married an American and [took] out citizenship in my own right, but she nonetheless felt acutely how Sylvia Pankhurst's casual description of her in The Suffragette Movement as having emigrated to America might have made difficulty for her.455
Later, MG and her mother moved from Monroe, New York, to Newark, New Jersey. After her marriage she moved to New York City, though not Manhattan.168

Between her arrival in the USA and her marriage, though MG may have worked briefly as an editorial assistant most of her employment was political in nature, as an organizer, public speaker, educational officer, and liaison officer with the press. Her employers included the Woman Suffrage Party of New York State and the National Consumers League (for whose study on Woman's Work in Wartime she did research among families in Wilmington, Delaware). She also worked for the Labor Party (later the Farmer-Labor Party) in Chicago (whose Women's Section occupied most of her energy), for the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America (for whom, briefly, she served as Director of Educational Programs), for the presidential campaign of Parley Parker Christensen, and for the League for Mutual Aid (of which she was executive secretary).

Suffrage was a compelling cause in the USA as in Britain: women had the vote in some states, but lacked it for federal elections until the Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution passed on 18 August 1920. During her first couple of years in America, MG worked for the Woman Suffrage Party of New York State, Brooklyn branch. For the National Consumers League, in 1918, she addressed herself to issues of women's wartime employment. This led her to work in support of a Minimum Wage Law in the state of Delaware, and then in turn to other labour issues, trade union issues, and the improvement of working-class education.238 Parley Parker Christensen, whose presidential campaign she worked on, was a leftist and civil libertarian. The League for Mutual Aid provided interest-free loans to those affiliated with labor and libertarian causes.371

These years of work and campaigning, in close continuity with her political work in Britain, were what MG felt to have been overlooked by Sylvia Pankhurst when the latter wrote that she emigrated to America, took up journalism, and married.450 It was true, MG said, that her public involvement decreased the year following her marriage, but the cause was once again her health.239

MG's political work took her to Buffalo and Rochester in New York, to Wilmington, Delaware, and to Chicago and Bellevue in Illinois. In Illinois and Indiana she spoke in mining districts, as she had done in Wales.

MG had English friends from the suffrage movement who were now, like her, in America, such as Beatrice Forbes-Robinson Hale.211 She worked with American suffragists such as Gertrude Franchot Tone and Mary Ogden White. White called her a morsel of a woman to have achieved so much . . . . She is all fire and quick response. She corresponded later with Parley Parker Christensen, whose campaign she had supported. Her friendship with Mary Dreier, born of shared politics, lasted her lifetime.460242

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG was married at Newark, New Jersey, to John Sanders, an American engineer.

SHORTPROSE.P: In writing about him she calls him the Engineer.39 He died in 1963, having become seriously ill a few years earlier. The marriage was childless.242, 247
With her new husband, MG moved from Newark to Whitestone, an area of the borough of Queen's, New York, where she lived for the rest of her life.

The two of them made a flying visit to England in 1933 and MG took her husband to Leeds, where they looked at several sites associated with her youth, and watched a cricket match at Headingly (though not to the end).39-40 They came back to England again for one or more brief visits during the 1950s.239

As a married woman MG did not engage in paid employment but continued to work as a volunteer with a number of progressive and labor organizations in New York City, particularly the New School for Social Research. Her hobbies included astrology, gardening, painting, and drawing.

MG's friendship with Dora Marsden ended in a breach. With Sylvia Pankhurst, too, her relationship later came to grief, but this was after a particularly close period following the birth of Sylvia's son on 3 December 1927. This was a difficult time for Sylvia, who was hounded by the press, disapproved of by her mother and sister, and seriously short of money. MG recognised Sylvia's right to be a mother without being a wife, and sent a baby gift; just over a year later the two women entered into regular correspondence.451-3 Gawthorpe helped publicize Pankhurst's The Suffragette Movement (1931) in the USA, even though she was upset by its footnote summarizing her own later suffrage activity in America, which she found totally inadequate and even potentially damaging to her US citizenship. Having enlisted support from a list of distiguished names to market the book in America, she later appealed to some of the same people to compel Pankhurst to issue a revised edition. They exchanged letters about this issue from 1931; in 1934 Gawthorpe's letters became angry; in 1935 she contacted a lawyer, and silence fell between these former friends.454-62

MG's correspondents included Emmeline Pethick-Lawrence, Alice Paul, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, Elizabeth Robins, Helena Swanwick, Henry Nevinson, Havelock Ellis, John Galsworthy, Victor Gollancz, A. R. Orage, Bertrand Russell, George Bernard Shaw, and C. P. Snow.459 When one of her former pupils, L. Dockray, approached her by letter in 1971 she called this resurrection of friendship one of the wonder experiences of my long life.243 and n33

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MG died at ninety-two, after a decade of widowhood, at the Clearview Nursing Home in Whitestone (Queen's), New York, USA. In England she had been imagined to be already dead for some years.
